Award.AwardTitle: The Dynamical Origin of Planetary System Architecture
Award.AbstractNarration: This project seeks to improve modeling of the final stages of planet formation by probing how planetary orbits change over time due to two possible physical causes: planet-planet gravitational scattering and tidal interactions. Gravitational interactions between planets can induce significant orbital changes, such as increased eccentricities, collisions between planets, and even ejection of planets from the system. Orbits may be also altered due to tidal forces between closer-in planets and their host star. Since the scattering and tidal effects depend critically on the planetary masses involved, the PI will also model the mass-frequency distribution of planetary systems. In particular, he will study the relationship between the initial planetary mass function (before scattering), and the observed planetary mass function of known planetary systems. The PI's modeling effort will run a series of N-body simulations of the gravitational interactions between planets, and tidal evolution to constrain how well these effects can explain observations of known exoplanet orbits and their current mass distributions. The PI will mentor undergraduate students in research who are participating in the University of Washington's ''Pre-Major in Astronomy Program.''

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project explored the role of orbital dynamics on the appearance and evolution of exoplanetary systems. Numerical simulations considered how gravitational interactions modify planetary systems over time, specifically examining how ejections of planets and energy dissipation by tides can give insight into planetary properties and the original configuration of exoplanetary systems. These properties and processes are not well-understood, and the outcomes from this project have significantly increased our knowledge of exoplanets.

     A major theme of this project was the orbital dynamics of exoplanetary systems. Orbital properties are often clues to formation processes and this project made important contributions to this area of study. One particularly interesting discovery is that extremely high amplitude chaos can occur in planetary systems with a mean motion resonance and large eccentricities and inclinations. The "Orbital Evolution" figure shows the evolution of one hypothetical system consisting of an Earth-like planet with a Neptune-like companion on a 3 year orbit. Despite the enormous orbital fluctuations, computer simulations found that this system will survive at least 10 billion years. For reference, the Earth's eccentricity and inclination remain below 0.05 and 3 degrees, respectively. We also found that planet-planet scattering, in which gravitational interactions remove planets, can result in systems similar to this one.  This result predicts future discoveries and gives us context for the Earth as a member of the galactic population of exoplanets. Perhaps some extraterrestrial life resides on worlds experiencing such extreme orbital and, hence, climatic fluctuations.

     We also tested the proposition that exoplanetary systems are shaped by the removal of original planetary members, a process called planet-planet scattering. Previous studies had mixed results, but we found that scattering can indeed reproduce the observed orbital behavior of exoplanets. Furthermore, this study was led by an undergraduate who was the first in his family to attend college and is now a graduate student in astronomy. This study filled a key objective of this project by constraining the pre-scattering planetary mass distribution and contributing to the higher education of a future scientist. 

        The role of tidal effects on planetary systems was also considered in depth, with a total of 11 peer-reviewed publication examining different aspects. A new tidal integrator code was developed that can quickly compare different models of tidal evolution, eqtide, which will be released in 2016. Eqtide was applied to stars, brown dwarfs, white dwarfs, exoplanets, exomoons and the Solar System, with a focus on exoplanets. For example, we found that certain planetary systems could form such that the tidal heating of an exoplanet is sufficiently large to instigate a runaway greenhouse. This would transform the planet into a hybrid of Venus and Jupiter's satellite Io, two of the most inhospitable worlds in our Solar System. The orbits of these "tidal Venuses" and other exotic planets that are shaped by tidal power and stellar radiation are shown in the "Planetary Classifications" figure.

        We also identified a promising new method to discriminate tidal models and tidal dissipation rates in exoplanets by leveraging large amounts of transit data. Current and future spacecraft will be capable of discovering tens of thousands of transiting planets with short orbital periods -- precisely the planets that experience significant tidal effects.
